The CCP continues to use vaccines as a propaganda tool against Taiwan. The tone has shifted from harsh criticism in May to softer appeal in the first 2 weeks of June. In our last Weekly, IORG has observed narratives such as â€œAmerica hasnâ€™t sold vaccines to Taiwanâ€ and â€œDPP not buying Chinese vaccines is being possessed by political demonsâ€ being spread by CPP agents to divide Taiwan-U.S. relations and criticize the Taiwan government. In this Weekly, IORG identifies the theme of â€œTaiwanese going to China to get vaccinated.â€ As an example, Chinese state media Global Times cited Taiwanese businessman XU Zheng-wen (å¾æ­£æ–‡) saying that â€œgetting vaccinated in China is safer and more convenient than in America.â€ A spokesperson of Chinaâ€™s Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) also claimed that â€œ62,000 Taiwanese have already been vaccinated in China.â€

XU Zheng-wen (å¾æ­£æ–‡) is a former member of Kuomingtangâ€™s Central Committee and a former guest member of CCPâ€™s Beijing Municipal Committee. He provoked controversy in February 2020 by inserting people who have contracted COVID-19 into a designated plane heading back to Taiwan.

According to IORGâ€™s Archive, at least 320 Facebook posts from Mandarin Facebook pages mentioned â€œTaiwanese going to China to get vaccinatedâ€ during the first 2 weeks of June. Also, at least 162 posts mentioned Taiwanese singers and actors going to China to get vaccinated, 129 of them (79.63%) mentioned Jam Hsiao (è•­æ•¬é¨°). These vaccinations echo the CCPâ€™s narrative and might influence the perception of the Taiwanese public towards getting vaccinated in China.

The CCP is simultaneously appealing softly to the need for vaccines in Taiwan and disseminating false information through state media outlets. Global Times reported that â€œDPP government is gifting 300,000 doses of AZ vaccines to its diplomatic allies.â€ Taiwanâ€™s Foreign Ministry was quick to clarify and deny. Hongkongâ€™s Wenweipo (æ–‡åŒ¯å ±) reported that â€œTaiwanese pork products tested excessive ractopamine.â€ While this report was contradictory to the testing results of Hongkongâ€™s Food and Environmental Hygiene Department and clarified by Taiwanâ€™s Council of Agriculture, at least 52 Facebook posts disseminated this narrative, particularly, posts from 11 Facebook pages contained content identical to Wenweipoâ€™s Weibo post, including pages supporting politicians JAN Jiang-tsun (è©¹æ±Ÿæ‘), HAN Kuo-yu (éŸ“åœ‹ç‘œ) and the Huang-fu-hsin (é»ƒå¾©èˆˆ) Taichung Chapter of KMT.

In the last Weekly, IORG has advised caution on continued appearance of vaccine-related suspicious narratives. During the first 2 weeks of June, we have found 2 containing false information: â€œJapanese Foreign Minister says Taiwan doesnâ€™t need many vaccines,â€ â€œTaiwan-produced Medigen vaccine and Moderna are like twins from the same originâ€, and 1 containing suspicious information: â€œU.S. company Blackwater invested in the R&D of Taiwanese vaccine UB-612.â€ In particular, the Blackwater-related narrative falsely cites a Reuters report and accuses the U.S. of using Taiwanese people as test subjects for vaccine R&D. These false and suspicious narratives could affect the perception of vaccines among the general public in Taiwan.

IORG would like to kindly alert our readers the possible occurrences of information manipulation related to â€œDo not take Japanese vaccines,â€ â€œDo not take Taiwanese vaccines,â€ or â€œVaccine distribution is unfair.â€ As Japanâ€™s Foreign Minister plans to provide additional vaccines to Taiwan, narratives that these vaccines are â€œleftovers,â€ â€œexpired,â€ â€œunsafe,â€ or â€œdeadlyâ€ might continue to appear. As the Taiwan-produced Medigen vaccine has concluded its phase 2 testing, narratives that it is â€œunsafeâ€ and â€œunrecognized by other countriesâ€ can lead to rejection of vaccination, affecting the effectiveness of epidemic prevention. Like always, IORG advises healthy skepticism careful fact-checking.
